intro: Reseda podolica, commonly known as the meadow catchfly, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its delicate, pinkish-purple flowers that bloom in summer. The plant typically grows in moist meadows and grasslands, reaching a height of about 20 to 60 centimeters. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while the stems are slender and branching. The seeds are small and enclosed in a capsule, which splits open to release the seeds when mature.
